loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his capital

loans.name: Florence Kasisa

texts.en:
Florence is a single 34-year-old lady and a mother of three children aged 12, 9 and 7 years respectively. They live in Huruma, which is in the outskirts of Nairobi town and a very populated area. Florence has a grocery stall where she sells food items such as vegetables, sweet potatoes, cereals and the like. Florence has been in this business for a period of three years now. This is her first loan from Kiva partner, KADET, and she plans to buy more sweet potatoes, green grams and kales so that she has enough stock in readiness for the high season.
Florence was introduced to KADET by a friend and has never borrowed from other financial institutions. She plans to grow her business, and buy a vehicle for a car hire business in the future. In this way she will be able to increase her monthly income to support her children and give them a good education.

loans.use: To buy sweet potatoes (10,000 KES), green grams (5,000 KES), onions (3,000 KES) and kales (2,000 KES)

loans.name: Ann Kaluki

texts.en:
Ann Kaluki, aged 52, has been running a boutique for the last two years. She is married to Andrew, aged 57, and together they have one son, John, who is 16 years old and in form three. She was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by the credit officer in charge of Kitengela office.
Ann's business gives her a monthly income of 14,300 KES. This loan of 50,000 KES is Ann's third loan with KADET and she has paid her previous loans well and on time. She intends to use this loan to buy clothes and shoes to sell during this Christmas holiday. If the loan boosts her business she will open another boutique in Machakos. Ann dreams of having many boutiques in Nairobi, Athi River and Machakos. She describes herself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy clothes and shoes for resale

loans.name: Sinet Ene

texts.en:
Sinet Ene T.  is 36 years old and runs a livestock farming business at Nkoile in Bissil, which is a remote area but with many customers. She is married to T. and together they have five children: Sopyato, 22, and Simon, 20, who are both in college; Beatrice, 15, in form one; Mary, 10, in class five; and Kapaayi, 6, in class one.  Sinet was introduced to KADET, Ltd. by the credit officer.

Sinet has been running this business for a period of 10 years and her monthly profit is 7,000 KES. This loan of 60,000 KES is her first loan with KADET and she plans to use 40,000 KES to buy cows and goats and 20,000 KES to open a butcher shop. If the loan boosts her business, she will pay school fees for her children.

Sinet desires to start a dairy farming activity in the future. She describes herself as hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: To buy cattle and start a butchery.

loans.name: Maana

texts.en:
Maana A. has a provision store at Ankaful near Abura. Maana has received no formal education.  She is married and has 4 children.  Maana has been selling provisions for 4 years now. She is responsible for assisting her husband in the payment of the family's bills.

Her loan will be used to buy a variety of provisions for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest into the provision business.

loans.use: to buy a variety of provisions for resale.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi K. is married and has 2 children. She has received no formal education. Esi sells charcoal at Ankaful near Abura, which she has done for quite some time now. Her husband is a farmer. Esi uses her income to assist her husband in the upkeep of the home.

Esi will use the loan to purchase more charcoal for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to reinvest back into the charcoal business.

She is standing by a few bags of charcoal in the picture.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is married and has 4 children. She has received no formal education. Rose sells a local food called Fante Kenkey (fermented corn dough wrapped in corn or banana leaves) which she makes herself at Ankaful near Abura.  She has done this for 2 years now. Her husband is a security man. Rose uses her income to assist her husband in the upkeep of the home.

Rose will use the loan to purchase more maize for the preparation of Fante Kenkey for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rose plans to reinvest back into the food business.

In her hand are a few balls of Fante Kenkey for display.

loans.use: to purchase more maize for the preparation of the Fante Kenkey for sale.

loans.name: 0307018 Tay Xuan Vi -Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Thuy N. T. (307018113) is a 27 year-old female living in the town of Hoang hoa. She is the leader of a five member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 0307018 Tay xuan vi -Hoang Hoa.

Thuy is married and has four infant children. To making a living, Thuy is starting a business venture in the food sector, namely a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling lake-caught fish in the local community. Thuy has been engaged in this business for over one year and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2010, Thuy joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,079,800 VND to purchase additional fish for resale. This will be her first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thuy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  Duong T. Tinh (114) is a 31 year-old female requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the services sector.

2.  V. T. Diu (115) is a 21 year-old female requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the services sector.

3.  C. T. Tuyet (116) is a 34 year-old female requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the services sector.

4.  N.  T. Be (117) is a 49 year-old female requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Thuy N. T. (307018113) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang hoa.  Thuy là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 0307018 Tay xuan vi -Hoang Hoa (0307018 Tay xuan vi -Hoang Hoa).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ thu hoạch & bán các loại cá đánh bắt ở hồ trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Thuy thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 1 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thuy kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND.  Vào 2010, Thuy đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  0    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 3,079,800 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1.  Duong T. Tinh (114) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

2.  V. T. Diu (115) là 21 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

3.  C. T. Tuyet (116) là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

4.  N.  T. Be (117) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish for resale.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. sells the root vegetable cassava. She also sells charcoal at Ankaful near Abura. Efua has received no formal education.  She is divorced and has 5 children.  Efua has been selling cassava and charcoal for 3 years now. She is responsible for paying school fees and other expenses for the children.

Her loan will be used to buy more charcoal and cassava for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into the charcoal business.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal and cassava for sale.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa N. is married and has 4 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Adjoa sells cooked rice with a variety of sauces at Ankaful near Abura, which she has done for 6 years. Her husband is a mason.

Adjoa uses her income to pay the school fees and other expenses of the children since her husband's income is too small to take care of all the expenses of the home. Adjoa will use the loan to purchase more bags of rice and other ingredients to cook for sale.

With the new profits from her expanded business, Adjoa plans to improve upon the quality of education of the children.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of rice and other ingredients to cook for sale.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi M. sells cooked food. She prepares local dishes like Banku (corn dough) and boiled yam with different types of sauces for sale at Ankaful near Abura. Esi has received no formal education.  She is married and has 5 children. Her husband is a mason.

Esi has been selling cooked food like Banku and boiled yam with sauce for 4 years now. She is responsible for assisting her husband with the upkeep and other financial responsibilities of the home.

Her loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs and a few other ingredients to cook for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into the food business.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuffs and a few other ingredients to cook for sale.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa A. sells bread which she bakes herself at Ankaful near Abura. Adjoa has received no formal education.  She is a single parent and has 1 child.

Adjoa has been selling bread for 3 years now. She is responsible for paying school fees, utility bills and other expenses for her child. Her loan will be used to increase her capital and to buy more ingredients to bake more bread for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into the bread business.

loans.use: to increase her capital and to buy more ingredients to bake more bread for sale.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian, 26, is a married woman living in Beirut with her husband and two children. Since 2009, she has owned an internet café and computer maintenance shop. She helps her husband in their family’s income and seeks to expand her business more and more. Vivian is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to upgrade her computers and add more to her shop in order to increase her income and expand her business. Her clients are of different ages, cultures and genders. She has a good reputation and everyone likes to deal with her.

loans.use: To buy new computers and upgrade existing ones.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal, 34, is married with two children, aged two and a half and four. She also takes care of two relatives aged 12 and 16. Her husband works in the military. Chantal runs a boutique selling bananas and other foodstuffs in the Gasabo district of Rwanda. She has been in this business for one year and her hours of operation are 6am to 6pm daily.  

Chantal has requested this loan through Vision Finance Company to expand her business. The extra income generated from this loan will help her to save for the future.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for resale.

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en:
Vanessa, 34, is married with one child. Her husband works as a driver. She sells bags and other goods in the Nyarugenge district of Rwanda. She has been in this business for about three years and her shop is open from 7am to 6pm every day except Saturdays.

Vanessa will use this loan to expand her business by adding more goods. Any profits made from the use of this loan will be reinvested in her business and she will be able to buy her own house for the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags for resale.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame I. is divorced and has six children. She has received no formal education. Maame sells a variety of soap at Ankaful near Abura, which she has been doing for the past five years. Maame uses her income to pay for school fees, utility bills and other expenses of her children. Maame will use the loan to purchase more soap for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to invest back into the soap sales.

loans.use: To purchase soap for resale.

loans.name: Baasandorj

texts.en:
Baasandorj T., 43, lives with his wife and three sons in the Hovd province of Mongolia. The family live live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in his brother's fence. The older two children attend a local high school and the youngest son is in kindergarten. 

Baasandorj and his wife operate the family business, a car repair service and machinery parts trading business, in their town, out of a rented shipping container. They started this business in 1996 and have since built a stable operation. At first, the couple rented a small stall to sell a variety of machinery parts but after a year of successful business operation, they managed to expand their business by renting a bigger work place, which is the container. Their earnings have enabled them to buy a plot of land and they hope to one day move to this land, after building a fence and connecting power.

For the future, Baasandorj plans to expand his car repair service. He is a hardworking man and is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to renovate his old tools and equipment for his car repair service and purchase more machinery parts from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to sell at his container.

loans.use: To renovate his old tools and equipment and purchase more machinery parts.

loans.name: Patricie

texts.en:
Patricie, 32, is married with three children aged 2 to 13. She has been selling shoes for about two years and her hours of operation are from 6am to 8pm daily.

Patricie has requested this loan through Vision Finance Company in order to sell different products. The extra income from this loan will help her business. In the future, she would like to create many projects which will earn profit.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes for resale.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline, 39, is married with five children aged 10 to 18. She has had her business for about eighteen years, operating from 6am to 8pm daily.

Jacqueline has requested a Kiva loan in order to expand her shop by adding cosmetics, foodstuffs such as tomatoes sauce, rice and different types of flour and other goods which seem to be in high demand in her business area.

With this loan, Jacqueline hopes to earn more profit than with her simple previous business. She will start saving, as well as improve her family situation.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell.

loans.name: Bathuu

texts.en: Bathuu M., 36, lives with his wife and three children in the Suhbaatar province of Mongolia. The family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent and fence. Uuganbayar operates his own shoe repair business out of a rented workplace at the local trade center. He began his business in 1999 and has since gained a lot of experience as a shoe repairer. Bathuu is a hardworking and modest man and says, "I want to start saving enough funds before my children attend university and I plan to open a savings account for my oldest daughter." He is requesting a 450,000 MNT loan to buy more repair supplies and tools for his business.

loans.use: To buy more repair supplies and tools.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica O. sells smoked fish at Ankaful near Abura. She has received a primary level of education, is married and has four children. Her husband is an auto mechanic. Veronica has been selling smoked fish for four years. She is responsible for assisting her husband in paying the family's bills. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to process for sale. She hopes to reinvest the additional profit back into her fish business.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish to process for sale.

loans.name: Jeanne Claire

texts.en:
Jeanne, 30, is married with two children aged two and ten. Her husband works as a teacher. She has had her business for about two years and currently employs six people. The hours of her business are from 5:30am to 9pm daily.

Jeanne has requested a Kiva loan in order to expand her restaurant by adding new offerings and developing the quantity and quality to satisfy her customers. With the additional profits from this loan, Jeanne will start saving, improve her family situation and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To expand her restaurant.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua S. is a single parent with three children. She has received no formal education. Ekua buys bags of rice and boxes of other items, such as canned tomatoes, and sells them to customers in smaller, more affordable quantities at Ankaful near Abura. She has been doing this for eight years. Ekua uses her income to pay school fees and other expenses of her children. She will use the loan to purchase more food stuffs for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more food stuffs for resale.

loans.name: Davaasambuu

texts.en:
Davaasambuu B., 51, lives with his wife and three children in the Uvs province of Mongolia. He and his family have lived together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent and fence, for past 25 years. His oldest daughter works as an accountant for the local hospital, his middle son serves in the Mongolian Military and his youngest son attends a local high school. 

Davaasambuu and his wife operate a retail flour business in their town. They have been engaged this business for the past 20 years and have gained a lot of experience over the many years. They have been earning enough money to greatly improve their quality of life. With their earnings, they were able to buy a car and garage for their family and business. They purchase flour in bulk at cheap prices and resell the flour at retail price. His monthly profits exceed 150,000 - 200,000 MNT. Davaasambuu is a talkative and open-minded person and says, "I am very thankful to you." He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase 65 bags of flours at wholesale price.

loans.use: To purchase 65 bags of flours at wholesale price.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa K. sells fruits, such as bananas, and cooks food for sale at Ankaful near Abura. She has received no formal education. Adjoa is married to a sanitary officer and has four children. She has been selling fruits for three years. She is responsible for assisting her husband with the upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more bags of rice and other ingredients to cook food to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and other ingredients to cook food to sell.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama B., who completed senior high school education, is married to a mason and has has one child. For four years now, Ama has been selling rice (in smaller plastic bags), and other food items at Ankaful near Abura. She is responsible for assisting her husband with the day to day running of the home.

Her loan will be used to buy more rice for sale. She hopes to reinvest the new profits arising from the loan back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice for sale.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba A. sells cooked beans and fried ripped plantain, which is commonly called "red red." She also works at a poultry farm, which she runs with her husband at Ankaful near Abura. Aba has received no formal education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a poultry farmer. Aba has been selling "red red" for 12 years now. She is responsible for assisting her husband in paying for the family's expenses. Her loan will be used to add to their capital to invest in the poultry farm. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest back into the poultry farm.

loans.use: Capital for poultry farm

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia A. is married to a security officer and has two children. She has received schooling through to junior high. Cynthia sells gari and fruits at Ankaful near Abura, which she has done for the past two years. She uses her income to assist her husband with the upkeep of the home. Cynthia will use the loan to purchase more fruits for resale. A. plans to reinvest the new profits back into her fruit-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits for resale.

loans.name: Jyldyzkan

texts.en:
Jyldyzkan A., 35, is an entrepreneurial woman who lives with her family in the north of Kyrgyzstan. She has four children aged four to ten and her husband works at the local state office as an accountant. In order to support her husband in covering all the family expenses, Jyldyzkan decided to start her own cattle breeding business. With 13,000 KGS as starting capital, she managed to develop a farm with four cows, forty sheep, five goats and five horses. To reduce expenses for the livestock's foraging, she pastures her livestock in the mountainous areas with native grasses.

Jyldyzkan plans to use this loan of 30,000 KGS to buy more cattle. With the revenues from the loan, she plans to expand her business and build a barn for her cattle.

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. It uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Rosa Mística Group

texts.es:
Para la formación el presente comité inició la Señora Rosa Ruíz  quién vive en la Zona del Km 7 CiuD. del Este quien contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en dicha zona 
En este comité la presidenta es la Sra. Rosa quien se dedica a la venta de ropas se encuentra muy contenta con sus socias del comité y desea continuar trabajando.

Ella solicito el préstamo para la compra de ropas como remeras, vestidos, shorts y otros para contar con mercaderías variadas para cliente.
texts.en:
This committee was founded by Rosa Ruíz D. who lives in Km 7 area of Ciudad Nueva.  She contacted her neighbors and friends to form a committee in her area. 

The president of this committee sells clothes.  She is very happy with the other members of her committee and would like to continue working.  She is requesting a loan to buy clothes such as t-shirts, dresses, shorts, etc. so that she can have a variety of merchandise to offer her customers.

loans.use: To buy t-shirts, dresses, etc.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ameyo Angèle

texts.fr: Mlle  Angèle est âgée  de   38 ans et fait la vente de produits congelés. Elle a commencé en 1990 cette activité et s’approvisionne  à Togo  Foods  et à Togo Frigo.  Elle revend ensuite ses produits  en  face du   marché  local  d’A..   Elle sollicite un prêt pour acheter 15 cartons  de volailles, 6 cartons  de  saucices  et  5 cartons de  poissons.
texts.en: Angèle is 38 years old and sells frozen foods. She began this business in 1990 and gets her supplies from Togo Foods and Togo Frigo. She then resells her products opposite the local market in A.. She is requesting a loan to buy 15 cartons of poultry, six cartons of sausages and five cartons of fish

loans.use: Purchase of frozen foods

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas 3 Group

texts.es:
El comité se Denomina  “Mujeres Unidas 3” están en el  Decimo  tercer ciclo  con  24  integrantes , es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias  y responsable entre ellas , las mismas  realizan labores para la recaudación de fondos para el grupo como: Rondas, Polladas y Sorteos.
Una de las integrantes del comité, una señora muy trabajadora y creativa en cuanto a su forma de trabajo, es la señora Alice. 
Ella actualmente se dedica a la atención de la despensa que posee en su casa y de esa forma mantiene ayuda a su familia, se encuentra muy satisfecha con el grupo que trabaja.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías como arroz, fideos, yerba mate, panificados y otros.
texts.en:
This committee is called “Mujeres Unidas 3” (United Women 3).  They are in their thirteenth loan cycle with 24 members.  This is a group that is well-known in their neighborhood for being very united, supportive and responsible.  They carry out activities to make funds for their group such as: competitions, lotteries and raffles.  

One of the committee's members is Alice who is a very hard-working and creative woman as far as her work is concerned.

Alice currently works serving in the small grocery store that she has in her home.  This is how she supports her family.  She is very satisfied with the group.  She is requesting a loan to buy merchandise such as rice, noodles, yerba mate, baked goods, etc.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, noodles, yerba mate, baked goods, etc.

loans.name: Mujeres Maravillas Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del comité inicio  la señora Adelaida G., quien vive en el km 7  barrio Mburucuja, ella contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la zona.
El comité se denomina “Mujeres Maravilla”, está constituido  por  17  señoras muy activas y solidarias todas de la misma zona. 
Ellas tienen actividades diferentes, otras  que emprenderán una nueva labor y cuentan con un  ingreso fijo. 
Una de las integrantes es la Ignacia quien se dedica a venta de ropas desde un puesto de venta que posee en su casa, para la atención del mismo la ayuda toda su familia dependiendo de la disponibilidad de cada uno. 
Ella comenta que viaja hasta en los países vecinos para la compra de las mercaderías  ya que ahí los precios son muchos bajos. 
Solicita el préstamo para la compra remeras, shorts, vestidos y otros.
texts.en:
This committee was founded by Adelaida G. who lives in Km 7 neighborhood, in Mburucuja.  She contacted her neighbors and friends to form a commitee in her area.

The committee is called "Mujeres Maravilla" (Wonder Women).  It has 17 very active and supportive members who are all from the same area.

Some of the women already have business activities, others have a regular income and are setting up new businesses.

One of the members of this committee is Ignacia who sells clothes from a sales location that she has set up in her own home.  Her entire family help her to serve in her store, depending on who is available.

Ignacia comments that she travels to neighboring countries to buy her merchandise since the prices there are much lower.  She is requesting her loan to buy t-shirts, shorts, dresses, etc.

loans.use: To buy t-shirts, shorts, dresses, etc.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
La Señora Hilda es cliente de nuestra institución desde el año 2009, está casada con el Señor Marciano Rolon, con quien son padres de 3 hijos, están domiciliados en Villa Elvira de Ciudad del Este. 
La misma es de profesión comerciante, posee un local comercial en el micro centro de la Ciudad, al costado de la Aduana, donde realiza la ventas de frazadas, y golosinas, se dedica a esta actividad hace varios años, agradece el apoyo financiero que la Fundación Paraguaya le otorgo.
Se trata de una persona con una visión prospera, de crecimiento y cabe resaltar la moralidad de pago con los compromisos asumidos con nuestra empresa.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de ropas como remeras, vestidos, y otros.
La señora Hilda es la de la izquierda  con la remera a rayas.
texts.en:
Hilda has been a client of our institution since 2009.  She is married to Marciano Rolon and they have three children together.  They live in Villa Elvira in Ciudad del Este. 

Hilda is a saleswoman.  She owns premises in the city's central business district, near the customs house.  She sells blankets and candy.  She has been in this business for several years and is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the financial support with which they have provided her.

Hilda is a person with a prosperous vision of growth.  We must highlight that she has always paid off her loans from our company responsibly.  She is requesting this loan to buy clothes such as t-shirts, dresses, etc.  Hilda is the women on the left of the photograph wearing a striped t-shirt.

loans.use: To buy t-shirts, shorts, dresses, etc.

loans.name: Terre Promise Plus Group

texts.en:
Maurice I. Mpango, 63, is the president of the Community Bank “Terre Promise Plus”, which means Promised Land in English. It is composed of 24 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Maurice started his business in 1998 selling beauty cream and miscellaneous products from his location in the north-eastern city of Kinshasa. He is a loyal client of MFI HOPE RDC and has already received two loans which he repaid properly. As demand is high in his community, he intends to use the next loan to increase his stock of goods and resell them with the aim of increasing his profits. Each week, his business brings in a profit of $30. His ambition is to become a wholesaler. 

Maurice is married and the father of six children, aged between 14 and 37. Four of his children go to school.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of goods for resale.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo
